instruction: Study the dictionary page below carefully and then answer the questions that follow.

question_text: Which group of words is arranged in alphabetical order?
Which of the following names would noramlly be written first in a class register?
Who discovered the Kaieteur Falls?

context.content:
Kaieteur Falls 

The Kaieteur Falls, was discovered on April 29, 1870 by the famous explorer, 
Charles Barrington Brown. It is situated on the Potaro River, a tributary of the 
Essequibo River in Guyana. 
The waters of Kaieteur, one of the natural wonders of the world, flow over a 
sandstone table and land into a deep valley- a drop of 7 41 feet or five times the 
height of Niagara Falls. Kaieteur takes the form of a huge column of water that 
flows into a rain bowed gully only to be transformed into a mountain of foam with a 
'billion eyes that fascinate'. 
There is no other waterfall in the world with the magnitude of the drop existing at 
Kaieteur. The width of the waterfall varies from 250 feet in the dry season to 
400 feet at the peak of the wet season: Amerindian legend of the Patamona tribe 
has it that Kaie, one of the tribe's great old chieftains, after whom Kaieteur is 
named, committed self-sacrifice by canoeing himself over the falls. He did this so 
that Makonaima, the great spirit, would save the tribe from being destroyed by the 
savage Caribisi. 

Adapted from https:l/wilderness-explorers. com/guyanaldaytrips/kaieteur
orinduik-falls. Retrieved 1 March 2017

question_text: Which statement about Kaieteur Falls is true?

context.content:
Kaieteur Falls 

The Kaieteur Falls, was discovered on April 29, 1870 by the famous explorer, 
Charles Barrington Brown. It is situated on the Potaro River, a tributary of the 
Essequibo River in Guyana. 
The waters of Kaieteur, one of the natural wonders of the world, flow over a 
sandstone table and land into a deep valley- a drop of 7 41 feet or five times the 
height of Niagara Falls. Kaieteur takes the form of a huge column of water that 
flows into a rain bowed gully only to be transformed into a mountain of foam with a 
'billion eyes that fascinate'. 
There is no other waterfall in the world with the magnitude of the drop existing at 
Kaieteur. The width of the waterfall varies from 250 feet in the dry season to 
400 feet at the peak of the wet season: Amerindian legend of the Patamona tribe 
has it that Kaie, one of the tribe's great old chieftains, after whom Kaieteur is 
named, committed self-sacrifice by canoeing himself over the falls. He did this so 
that Makonaima, the great spirit, would save the tribe from being destroyed by the 
savage Caribisi. 

Adapted from https:l/wilderness-explorers. com/guyanaldaytrips/kaieteur
orinduik-falls. Retrieved 1 March 2017

question_text: The word "dense" in line 2 tells us that the plants in the forest were

context.content:
One night, a farmer was returning home from a cattle fair with the bull that he had 
bought. As he passed through a dense forest, a robber who was hiding in the 
thick undergrowth jumped in front of him. The robber had a large stick in his hand. 
He said, "Hand over all that you have."

The farmer got scared and grudgingly handed what he had to the robber. As he 
turned to go, the robber said, "Give me the bull, too. Why are you taking it away?" 
The farmer handed over the bull's rope to the robber and then begged, "Since you 
have taken everything from me, can you give me your stick?" "Why do you need 
it?" the robber enquired of the farmer. 
"Well, my wife will be pleased that at least I got a stick from the fair," replied the 
farmer. 

The robber happily gave the stick to the farmer. Within a flash, the robber, leaving 
the bull and the farmer's money behind, was running away for dear life. 

Anonymous
